content.webTitle: Tim Atkin: Four red wines for grown-ups

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.bodyText: 2003 Navasques Tempranillo, Navarra (£4.49, Morrison's; Safeway) At the cheaper end of the spectrum, I'd rather drink inexpensive reds from Navarra than neighbouring Rioja. This is a juicy, unoaked Tempranillo with fresh, strawberry fruit and a nip of tannin. 2003 Capitel dei Nicolai Valpolicella Classico Superiore, Tedeschi (£6.99, Sainsbury's) This ridiculously under-priced Italian red is rich, dry and concentrated with notes of tea leaves and dried fruits. The wine is deliciously balanced with a finish that lasts for minutes. 2003 Petalos del Bierzo, Descendientes de J Palacios (£9.99, Corney & Barrow, 020 7265 2400) Made entirely from the little-known Mencia grape in the wilds of north-west Spain, this is a spicy, old-vine red that reminded me of Cote Rotie. It's peppery, concentrated and nicely oaked with flavours of plums and blackberries. 2001 Bowen Estate Coonawarra Shiraz (£13.99, The Australian Wine Club, 0800 856 2004; www.australianwine.co.uk) Doug Bowen makes some of the most elegant wines in Australia. This finely crafted, scented, complex, age-worthy Shiraz disproves the theory that Coonawarra is better suited to Bordeaux varieties like Cabernet Sauvignon.
